 THE RUSSIAN FEDERATION RUSSIAN BUREAU OF ECONOMIC ANALYSIS PROJECT I. INTRODUCTION 1.1 In the short span of fifteen years, policy analysis has become a mainstay of modern economic management. As distinct from policy research, which is more academic and less time-bound, policy analysis is tied to a specific decision point in government. Policy analysts, who are generally trained in economics and statistics, consider both the consequences of alternative public policy choices and the likelihood of their implementation. Public agencies in industrialized economies rely heavily on policy analysts and when the desired skill base is lacking in government they turn to consultants for specialized advice. In some cases, consulting firms or institutes fill government needs when civil service or other prohibitions prevent the analysts from being hired directly.!' 1.2 Capacity for economic policy analysis has been steadily improving in Russia since 1992, but is still very weak both in and outside government. Capacity constraints are becoming acute as the reform agenda grows more complex. The Government of Russia (GOR) succeeded in reducing consumer price inflation by reducing the fiscal deficit. The stabilization effort is being supported by a three-year Extended Fund Facility (EFF) arrangement agreed with the IMF in March 1996. With the most evident deficit reduction measures already taken, Russia needs to deepen structural reforms to sustain macroeconomic stability and lay the basis for sustained growth. 1.3 The Bank has worked closely with the IMF and the Government to develop a comprehensive agenda of structural reforms in areas such as privatization and enterprise restructuring, financial sector reform, fiscal management, and the social safety net. Further work is required in each area to translate this agenda into a detailed and monitorable package of policy actions. This will entail intensive economic policy analysis to assess options that maximize allocative efficiency and promote welfare. 1.4 However, elaboration of structural reform programs, and economic management more generally, are complicated by the shortage of qualified economists in Government and by an institutional setting for economic policy advice that is fragmented and in flux. The Government recognized the limitations of employing ad hoc working groups during development of the EFF and requested Bank support to build more sustained institutional capacity in public agencies for high-quality economic policy analysis. 1/ Weimer, D. and Vining, A., Policy Analysis: Concepts and Practice, Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey: Prentice Hall, pp. 9-11. -1 -

THE INSTITUTIONAL SETTING 2.1 Economic management and structural reform are complicated in Russia by an institutional setting for economic policy advice that is fragmented and in flux. As views on the state's role in the economy change, the market for economic advice is realigning both in terms of supply (economic research institutes) and demand (from the President, Government, Duma, and the business community). A. Supply and Demand for Economic Advice 2.2 As of 1991, there were 61 economic research institutes in Moscow specializing in theoretical and applied economic research. Most (54) were attached to ministries and state committees, including GOSPLAN, while the remainder were part of what became the Russian Academy of Sciences. They were funded almost entirely from the budget. Although overstaffed and ideologically oriented, the system after 1985 was sufficiently permissive to allow individual economists to be exposed to market- economy principles. The first wave of reformers and business elites emanated from this community. 2.3 By 1994, prompted by enthusiasm for market principles, the number of organizations carrying out economic research grew by 30 percent. They sought to fill the demand by business interests and Government for analysis of current economic trends. The older institutes, which retained a mentality more suited to the central allocative mechanism of the Soviet state and its branch and functional ministries, were neither oriented nor positioned to meet the more short-term needs of the emerging market. Their best researchers left, some to the new independent institutes, whose principal clients are outside Government. Funding channels remained largely unchanged (directed by ministries to affiliated institutes), but budget support declined on average by 40-60 percent while overheads (social security and utilities) escalated. The financial squeeze forced the institutes to seek income from sources other than their traditional public-sector clients. Nevertheless, salaries in scientific and economic research were, by 1993, 35 percent lower than the economy-wide average. 2.4 Meanwhile, given the turbulent political background, the focus of strategic economic decisions and their implementation has been shifting. There is increased demand for economic analysis from the Duma, but it generally parallels the political outlook of the faction requesting advice. Governmental ministries, not fully aware of their role in a transition economy, continue to request traditional but short-lived programming documents from affiliated institutes. 2.5 The resulting reduction and consolidation of economic research institutes has been uneven, such that weaker institutes may enjoy partial funding while some stronger institutes are at risk. The still developing situation is not yet market-driven in that the present structure reflects neither the comparative advantage nor the quality of the institutes. Increased funding from private sources for these institutes is -4 -
 not a solution for government, given the potential conflict of interest in many sensitive areas of economic policy. B. Institutional Framework 2.6 In addition to the imperfect supply and demand structure, three institutional issues are inhibiting the flow of economic advice in support of macroeconomic and structural reforms: Lack of Analytical Objectivity. The market is "feudalized" into domains dominated by a particular individual, group of interests, or government institution. In the unstable climate, institute tasks and functions are often hostage to political or vested interests. * Disconnectionfrom Policy Process. With few exceptions, institutes do not enjoy access to current information or to senior decision-makers (Deputy Prime Minister level and above). Most are independent or report to ministries or state departments that technically fall outside of Government. Research funded from external sources is at particular risk of having little influence on the decision-making process. Incoherent Policy Advice. The fragmentation of advice along narrow issues, provided to multiple government users, has prevented the emergence of more coherent macroeconomic or "general equilibrium" framework for decision-making. 2.7 As noted in the next section, these difficulties were temporarily overcome from 1992-95 through an ad hoc arrangement that developed outside existing institutional channels. 2.8 Economic Policy Advice in Support of the Reform Program, 1992-96. During 1992-96, the economic reform program was developed and managed by a handful of reformist Government officials. Most were located in the core economic ministries (Finance and Economy) under the First Deputy Prime Minister for Economic Affairs or in GKI (State Property Agency). Their ability to drive the policy agenda, however, was unrelated to their institutional affiliations. More important was their participation, in 1992-94, in the Working Center for Economic Reform, or after 1994, on the Economic Reform Commission under the First Deputy Prime Minister for Economy. While ostensibly part of Government, both bodies functioned more as in-house consulting firms to senior policy-makers. These two groups, whose members overlapped, were the central nervous system of the reform program. They developed and coordinated the macroeconomic stabilization and structural reform agenda underlying the Bank's two Rehabilitation Loans, SAL I, and the Fund's Stand-by Arrangement and EFF. 2.9 The analytical needs of the reformist officials were met in the early stages primarily by two Government institutions: the Center of Economic Forecasting and Analysis and the Center of Information and Social Technologies. These had important advantages over other existing institutes because they were granted access to current information and exposure to the policy process. Systematic linkages between the core economic policy team and the older institutes atrophied. - 5-
 2.10 At the same time, efforts to increase capacity in the core economic ministries was initially constrained by the shortage of qualified economists and low civil service payscales. As new graduates with high-quality training began appearing in 1994, and external financing for international and Russian economic expertise became available, the problem was temporarily eased. In the Ministry of Finance, the matching of international expertise with recent graduates dramatically increased the Ministry's capacity for macroeconomic modelling and analysis, which has been a critical component in the success of stabilization efforts.4' 2.11 Recently, however, the cream of the younger talent pool has begun to leave the core ministries for better remuneration in the private sector, and reliance on international experts, never an ideal solution, cannot be maintained indefinitely. Due to financial constraints, the Center of Economic Forecasting and Analysis has nearly ceased operations while the Center of Information and Social Technologies has closed. All of the remaining institutions in research and policy analysis have been weakened by under-funding and competition from the private sector. Capacity is insufficient to handle the quantity of cross-sectoral analysis required for second-stage transition issues. 2.12 In summary, a critical demand has appearedfor objective and coherent economic policy advice to inform strategic economic decisions during the next stage of the transition. This demand cannot be met by the skill base presently available in existing institutes and ministries. Nor would the strengthening of a single existing governmental structure provide a sustainable solution given civil service restrictions that affect all publicly-supported ministries and institutes. C. Plans and Programs The Government 2.13 The Government's medium-term economic strategy includes actions to: (i) continue a restrained macroeconomic policy stance as a precondition for sustained growth; (ii) strengthen Russia's capacity to implement macroeconomic policy through the introduction of requisite instruments and institutions; and (iii) advance structural reforms that can consolidate stabilization and enhance prospects for sustained growth. 2.14 As part of its capacity-building strategy, the Government requested Bank financing to support the establishment of the BEA. The initial request for financing, proposed in October 1995 by the First Deputy Prime Minister for Economy, was confirmed in a letter to the President of the World Bank by the Minister of Economy in April 1996 and again to the President by the First Deputy Prime Minister for Economy in Moscow in April 1997. In the absence of the project, a structural reform agenda as ambitious as that agreed with the IMF will-be difficult to implement. Independent of the EFF, however, the demand for sound economic policy advice will outpace existing institutional capacity as more complex second-stage transition issues supersede the stabilization-oriented agenda of the past several 4/ Financing for the Ministry of Finance's macroeconomic unit has come from the EU, US Treasury, and World Bank. -6 -

The BEAP responds to the high priority placed by government on grounding the next phase of reforms in objective economic analysis External Donor Assistance 2.15 Most donors have targeted elements of the reform agenda for support, such as privatization or agriculture. Few have focussed on strengthening capacity for cross-sectoral policy analysis. The IMF, EU, USAID, Bank and other organizations have made important contributions in building skills related to public finance and fiscal policy, including in the Ministry of Finance and Central Bank. But the needs in government for analytic capacity far outweigh the aid provided to date. 2.16 There are several organizations which could be counterparts to the BEA, for which twinning arrangements would be very useful. Economic policy institutes have flourished internationally in the last fifty years. Although these institutes or councils differ greatly from one country to the next in terms of their size, modus operandi, and institutional arrangements, some key factors distinguish effective institutes. The central factor determining success is that the research and policy advice of the institute is viewed as a national priority. This and other factors, which have been noted in designing the project, include: * association with a powerful government agency while remaining outside the formal bureaucracy; * direct access to/influence on key policymakers; * secure sources of financing; * staff composed of a small but elite group of top academics in the economics field; * attractive and competitive salaries to retain top academics; and * a clear mandate to conduct economic research and formulate policy in the best interests of the national economy as a whole. - 10 -

Project Objectives 4.1 Due to shortcomings in the institutional framework, the Government has very limited capacity to produce cross-sectoral analyses grounded in modern, market-based economics. This has constrained the development and implementation of structural and market-oriented reforms. The proposed project will address the principal institutional shortcomings and demonstrate the value of objective economic policy advice as an essential component of national economic policymaking. 4.2 The principal development objective of the project is to build institutional capacity for sound economic analysis in support of market-oriented and structural reforms. To meet this objective, the project has three sub-goals: a. to increase the quantity and quality of cross-sectoral economic policy studies for use by Government; b. to establish the BEA outside of Government but accountable to it, to provide an objective, economy-wide perspective in assessing economic policy options; and c. to improve the reliability of the national accounts as the basis for sound economic analysis. 4.3 The performance indicators (Appendix 1) were agreed at negotiations. They are designed to monitor both the project outputs and impacts in terms of their utility, quality, and efficiency of production. Project outputs will provide for sounder economic analysis based on more reliable National Accounts and economic data and the integration of macroeconomic and welfare considerations into sectoral and economic reform options. The principal project impact is expected to be the preparation of detailed action plans in support of the Government's medium-term economic reform agenda. Based on project outcomes, the Government is expected to positively assess the value of retaining this institutional model. B. Project Description 4.4 The project will finance three components: a. Policy Studies (US$11.0 million). This component would finance four products: (i) an annual report on the state of the economy; (ii) quarterly indicators of economic performance; (iii) medium-term policy studies on cross-sectoral topics in support of the structural reform agenda; and (iv) quick-response notes in response to developments in the policy environment. The BEA would manage the budget for delivery of these products, which could generally be produced in cooperation with economic agencies and/or institutes. - 11 -
 b. Establishing the Bureau of Economic Analysis (US$17.5 million). Included in the BEA component are several categories of investment and incremental recurrent costs needed to establish the BEA, build capacity in policy analysis, and develop technical and institutional linkages to domestic and international institutes. c. Improvement of National Accounts (US$6.8 million). The component would finance computers, training, and technical assistance to help Goskomstat, the national statistical agency, accelerate its present efforts to develop an integrated framework of national accounts useful for economic and financial analysis and policy decisions. 4.5 Policy Studies (US$11.0 million). Development and implementation of the Government's structural reform agenda will require in-depth analyses from an economy-wide perspective, taking into account the inter-relationships among industries, taxpayers and consumers. To this end, the BEA would manage the budget for production of a number of outputs, some of which may be produced in collaboration with other agencies or institutes, but with the BEA maintaining quality control. The most important output would be medium-term policy studies in several areas (see Appendix 11), including macroeconomic analysis and growth strategies, financial markets, enterprise economics and social policy. Financing would be provided for local consultants, data requirements such as surveys, and if necessary, international experts to assist in the completion of each study, which is expected to take approximately three to six months. These studies will be focused on high-priority themes (for example, taxation or pension reform) that are expected to lay the basis for significant policy decisions that are likely to impact savings and investments and fiscal revenues and expenditures. These studies would be the BEA's core product, consuming approximately 50 percent of its time. The themes chosen for the studies would provide the central chapters of the annual report on the state of the economy, which would also discuss economic trends and conditions based on the quarterly economic indicators produced by the BEA. Production of the annual report and quarterly indicators are expected to consume another 25 percent of the BEA's time. The BEA will also need flexibility to respond to requests from senior officials on developments in the policy environment. For this purpose, approximately 25 percent of the BEA's time is expected to be spent producing quick-response policy notes. 4.6 Bureau of Economic Analysis (US$17.5 million). The justification for establishing the BEA, its governance structure, and operational procedures are discussed in Chapter 5. This component would finance the technical and human resource base needed to increase capacity for economic policy analysis both in the BEA and in the core economic ministries. These expenditures would include: (i) computer and information technology needed for the BEA's statistical analysis and for linkages with Goskomstat, the core economic ministries, and Russian and international academic institutes. Included in this activity would be development of a library and on-line databases to facilitate the research needs of its staff and consultants; (ii) training, study tours and fellowships both for BEA staff and for government staff participating in policy studies, to develop analytic skills based on modern, market-based economics in core economic agencies; and (iii) office furnishings to establish the BEA's premises. The incremental recurrent costs, to be financed on a declining basis, would include managerial and support staff salaries, internal communications (meetings of the Boards of Trustees and Directors and Academic Council), and publications. 4.7 The BEA component would also include the budget of the External Outreach Program (Appendix 13), which will produce and distribute the annual report and quarterly economic indicators and promote exchanges between the BEA and academic institutes, both in Russia and abroad, by means of conferences, - 12 -
 seminars, and twinning arrangements. The purpose of the External Outreach Program will be to further cooperation within Russia and internationally on economic policy issues in the BEA's work program. 4.8 Cooperation with the Economic Development Institute (EDI) of the World Bank. Given its experience internationally and in the region, EDI is well-positioned to provide BEA with assistance in many areas, and in particular, training on economic policy analysis with a sectoral focus and technical assistance on consensus-building and dissemination of analytical work. A formal arrangement is under discussion whereby EDI will assist BEA in identifying training needs in policy analysis, and by developing the first two training seminars for BEA staff and consultants and selected ministry staff. In addition to offering technical assistance and training, BEA professional staff may compete for access to EDI programs such as: (i) mid-level career training at the Joint Vienna Institute; (ii) a Scholarship Program for study at any accredited university worldwide; and (iii) the Robert McNamara Fellowship for post-graduate research. After the BEA has developed its policy study and external outreach programs, EDI will consider establishing a formal partnership with the BEA, which would provide a stronger network of training and institutional support. 4.9 Improvement of National Accounts (US$6.8 million). The main economic policy tools (fiscal, monetary, and exchange rates) of a market economy cannot be applied on a sound basis to promote growth with stability unless a good set of national accounts and data on other macroeconomic variables are available. Goskomstat, the state statistical agency, has initiated several measures to adjust to the data needs of a market economy and to compile GDP estimates through the production and expenditure approaches based on the 1993 System of National Accounts (SNA). Despite notable progress both in Goskomstat and by other data-collecting agencies, additional work is needed to accelerate the development of an integrated framework of the national accounts. The component would make a significant contribution to this objective by financing computer equipment, training and technical assistance needed to improve the quality of economic statistics by improving data collection, upgrading the information base, and by refining the methodology of computations. The work program would follow the recommendations in Russian Federation: Report on the National Accounts, produced in October 1995 by a Joint Team including Russian agencies, led by Goskomstat, and international experts, led by the World Bank. C. Project Management and Evaluation 4.10 Project Management. The Borrower shall make the proceeds of the Loan available to BEA and Goskomstat on a grant basis. The Borrower agreed that the project would be managed in accordance with an Agent Agreement between the Ministries of Finance and Economy, on one hand, and the BEA, on the other. The Agent Agreement specifies the mechanism for payment of the local cost contribution and taxes on the part of the Borrower. According to the Agent Agreement, which must be signed as a condition of loan effectiveness, BEA is obligated to facilitate the strengthening of institutional capacity in government agencies in the area of economic policy analysis and studies, and to support the implementation of Part C of the Loan (Goskomstat component) through procurement and disbursement services. The respective roles of BEA and Goskomstat in project implementation are outlined in the Operations Manual. In summary, all substantive matters regarding the improvement of the National Accounts would be managed by Goskomstat, and BEA would make available its expertise in procurement and disbursement for this purpose to Goskomstat. - 13 -

Approach and Justification 5.1 The Government continues to develop and implement structural reform programs and national economic policy with only minimal levels of analytic support grounded in the framework of modern market-based economics. It has attempted to obtain the policy studies and analyses needed with a variety of ad hoc arrangements relying on both Russian and foreign experts located in both governmental units and non-governmental institutes. Experience has highlighted the shortcomings of this approach: * Analysis and advice currently provided is fragmented, tends not to be cross-sectoral or cross-ministerial, and varies widely in quality. * Current government procedures (civil service salaries, incentives for quality, etc.) are insufficient to attract and retain staff with the required skills within the government and, hence, to sustain needed analytic capacity. a Procuring services from private institutes or consulting firms is not a good substitute for the government having its own capacity, given the need for confidentiality and lack of scale economies stemming from distributing work among many groups. * Government experience with grant financed foreign experts has strengthened its belief that it must have capacity funded by resources under its control. 5.2 The BEA is proposed to remedy these shortcomings. It will be a major source for the government of policy reports, studies, and reports on economic issues, and it will report regularly to the government on the state of the economy. Its status as a foundation outside the government would free it from governmental procedures and constraints. The presence on the BEA's governing boards of representatives from its clients-the major units of the federal government with principal responsibility for economic policy-would assure the BEA's responsiveness and accountability to governmental needs. 5.3 The BEA is a non-commercial entity set up as a foundation under Russian law. It will therefore not be restricted by governmental salary scales or personnel practices, and will be in a position to offer levels of remuneration and support facilities that will allow it to compete effectively with the private sector for the high quality staff required to produce the products needed by policy makers. An Academic Board will help to ensure the quality of its staff and its output. The BEA's position outside the government will ensure the independence and objectivity of its work and increase its ability to take a cross-sectoral or cross-ministerial view of economic issues. - 15 -

Within this objective, the three principles guiding the selection and orientation of BEA's analysis will be growth, efficiency and equity. Using these principles, the Board of Directors has identified the highest priorities for studies in the medium-term as being in macroeconomic analysis and public finance, financial sector reform and enterprise economics, social policy and growth strategies. Topics would be selected after the completion of an overview paper that identifies the major problems amenable to policy reform and assigns priorities to the analysis of each problem. Priorities for analysis will be determined by rough estimates of: (i) the pay-off from policy reform; (ii) the costs of reform; and (iii) the likely speed or realizable schedule of policy reform. The assignment of priorities will be based mainly on economic costs and benefits, although at times judgments about the political feasibility of reform will be needed. High priorities for analysis will be those that produce large net benefits quickly. 5.20 The BEA will work within an economy-wide perspective and consequently take into account the inter-relationships between industries, consumers and taxpayers. In particular, the BEA will test the claims of those proposing sector or enterprise-specific advantages through regulation or protection. Both through a unit specialized in social sector analysis and, where feasible, by incidence analysis of impact of policy options on households, the BEA would seek to advance the Government's welfare objectives in making these assessments. F. Legal Framework 5.24 Rationale for Non-Commercial Foundation Status. The BEA was established as a non- commercial foundation, which is a legally autonomous entity pursuant to the Civil Code. This legal status allows the BEA to have independence and thus, greater objectivity in its analytic work. Moreover, civil service salary scales are not sufficient to attract the quality economists needed for it to become a viable policy analysis institute, and Russian law prohibits civil servants from receiving payments that exceed official salary scales. The establishment of BEA as a non-commercial foundation followed the precedent set in several Bank projects, including the Management and Financial Training Project (3824-RU) and the Legal Reform Project (4035-RU), under which the National Training Foundation and the Foundation for Legal Reform were founded as non-commercial foundations. 5.25 Accountability to the Government. Nevertheless, the BEA will be accountable to Government by means of its Charter, the Government decree permitting the BEA's establishment (Decree # 1025 dated July 1, 1996), a second Government decree (to be issued) establishing the regulatory framework for Government participation in the BEA, and the documentation supporting the Bank Loan. As a condition of negotiations, the Government confirmed the First Deputy Prime Minister for Economy as Chairman of the Board of Trustees. The General Assembly, which approved the Charter and appointed the Boards of Trustees and Directors, is comprised of the principal economic agencies of Government, including the Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Economy, Central Bank, Goskomstat, the State Property Committee (GKI) and the State Anti-Monopoly Committee. Well-respected academic institutes, including the Academy of National Economy and the Higher School of Economics, comprise the remainder of the institutional representatives on these bodies. The BEA has been established pursuant to a Government decree. The Charter requires a majority of the Boards of Trustees and Directors to be representatives of governmental agencies. In addition to the Loan Agreement between the Bank and the Borrower (GOR), the BEA agreed on the contents of a Project Agreement with the Bank. 5.26 Legal Establishment of the BEA under Russian Law. The BEA was registered with the Ministry of Justice according to Russian law, for which it had to complete the following actions to establish itself as a legal foundation: (i) convened a Founders' meeting, at which time the Founders, which are required to be non-governmental institutions, invited governmental bodies to join as Participants - 20 -

Each of these steps has been completed. Given that the BEA is registered as a legal entity, it can officially open a bank account and hire staff. G. Cost Recovery, Budget and Financing Mechanisms 5.27 Cost Recovery. In order to lay the basis for financial sustainability over the medium term, the BEA will require that agencies contribute to the cost of each study. The BEA will need to develop a reputation for excellent analytical work in order to derive significant cost recovery for its studies. Until such reputation is established, the BEA has reached agreement with the Ministry of Economy on interim procedures to govern MOE's contribution to the first-year work program. Thereafter, the Scientific Secretary will be designated as the BEA official in charge of business development for the purpose of canvassing client ministries to assess cost recovery potential. The objective would be to express the needs of client ministries as actual and specific demand supported by funding. 5.28 Budget and Financing Mechanisms. BEA's budget will depend on its work program, which will in turn dictate its human resource needs. The first-year staff and consultant budget was developed by BEA and approved by the Bank on the basis of the draft work program. It is expected that this will evolve with experience during the course of the year, on which basis amendments would be needed for the following year's budget. Similarly, BEA's financing plan will evolve annually according to improvements in cost recovery. Consequently, BEA agreed that, by an agreed date each year, BEA shall submit to the Bank for review its proposed budget andfinancing plan, which must be satisfactory to the Bank. The Government will finance its share of BEA's annual expenditures through the Ministry of Education, which will in turn pass the funds to the BEA. The financing mechanism is included in an Agent Agreement between the Ministry of Finance and BEA. As a condition of negotiations, the Government provided a draft Agent Agreement, which was acceptable to the Bank, that specifies the commitment of the Borrower to contribute its local cost share, as identified in the annual budget. Signing of the Agent Agreement between the BEA and Borrower is a condition of loan effectiveness. - 21 -

PROJECT BENEFITS AND RISKS Benefits 7.1 The principal project benefit in the short term will be the preparation of detailed action plans in support of the Government's medium-term structural reform agenda. These would result from the BEA's ability -- based on access to the necessary skills, data, and collaboration with economic agencies -- to provide and mobilize high-quality economic policy advice directly to decision-makers in Government, and to help integrate macroeconomic and welfare considerations into sectoral and economy- wide reform agendas. Without the project, the lack of systematic and well-coordinated economic analysis, especially in the design and implementation of structural reforms, is likely to persist. 7.2 As a result of the project, the Government is expected to retain and enhance the capacity in governmental institutions for analytic economic work. The fellowships/training in mainstream economics and policy analysis financed by the project, as well as increased experience in coordinating policy development across ministries, will lay the basis for sustainable improvements in Government capacity once the loan closes. The project will finance a Training Needs Assessment for economic policy analysts in Government, that will guide BEA training strategy. Therefore, a principal benefit in the medium-term will be sounder economic analysis based on more reliable National Accounts and improved capacity for cross-sectoral analysis. Risks 7.3 The accountability of the Bureau to Government poses risks that are common to all governmental advisory bodies. The first is that the BEA's influence may rise or fall depending upon the interests and status of its government sponsors. While close association with the office of the First Deputy Prime Minister is the most appropriate arrangement at present, flexibility is needed in the event of institutional changes. Second, the closer the association with senior government officials, the more the work program may become influenced by political considerations. While accountability is important to increase the BEA's impact, too close an association can undermine its analytic objectivity. The present governance structure combines governmental and non-governmental representatives, with a certain degree of flexibility to change the balance of power between them depending upon the circumstances. It also combines accountability to a senior Government official -- the First Deputy Prime Minister -- with accountability to economic ministries. This should help maintain the benefits of analytic objectivity while minimizing the risks resulting from accountability to Government. However, the tension between objectivity and accountability exists in all governmental advisory bodies and cannot be removed entirely by the project design. - 30 -
 7.4 Another risk is the lack of a tradition of coordination and information-sharing across layers of Government and among economic agencies, which is critical for cross-sectoral analysis. Rather, authority tends to be concentrated in institutions headed by prominent individuals, who prefer to compete rather than cooperate. The governance structure of the BEA has been designed to reduce the risk of insularity by giving authority to a broader group of stakeholders (economic agencies and institutes) who would both direct the BEA and be its primary clients. This will particularly be the case for Goskomstat, without which the data requirements for economic analysis could not be met. 7.5 Finally, the staff recruitment process may not be sufficiently competitive to meet the quality standards required to maintain the BEA as a center of excellence. This is a particular risk with enclave projects because it can intensify institutional rivalries with civil servants. The risk is further intensified if first-year products are less than exemplary. This risk has been discussed at length with BEA management and various strategies have been developed in response. First, technical criteria for each staff position have been developed. These would be monitored through observance of compliance with the Bank's procurement process (competitive selection) and by the quality control function of the Academic Council, which will review requirements for staff qualifications as well as candidates for individual positions. Second, a training program for all BEA analysts and their key counterparts in government will take place in the first year on the National Accounts framework and in analytic techniques, to establish a quality standard in the early phase of the project. Finally, international expertise or study tours are required as inputs to all policy studies up to and including year three of the project. - 31 -

 2 1. Macroeconomic Monetary Policy The state still retains a strong position in the Russian economy and protectionism in the form of subsidizing losses due to mismanagement and hopeless loss-making production entities has not been eradicated. However, the role of the state in regulating economic processes is still weak and ill-defined. In the macroeconomic sphere monetary regulatory bodies have managed to achieve control of the main ruble aggregates. The circulation of surrogate money, however, is totally unregulated. The issue of surrogates is a serious brake on the implementation of macroeconomic policy leading to growing defaults on payments and errors in forecasting the main macroeconomic indicators, including the GDP. It raises the question of the prospects of the development of this segment of money circulation. Another problem is the lack of adequate macroeconomic forecasting instruments, which prevents evaluation and analysis of medium-range prospects of economic development of Russia. Features of the present-day macroeconomic policy. Considering the very mixed results of progress towards the market at the macro level, including the monetary sphere, an analysis of macroeconomic policy in the context of slow structural reform is imperative. The search for macroeconomic solutions calls for the study of a number of specific short-term trends caused by the flaws in the structural and institutional policy in the transitional period. The implementation of the monetary policy in turn requires that two priority issues be addressed: a) how to diminish the role of surrogates in money circulation; and b) to what extent and due to what causes the danger of further dollarization of the Russian economic persists. Middle-range macroeconomic policy prospects. An analysis of this problem presupposes first and foremost a development of a model for medium-range macroeconomic forecasting. Attempts to develop such a model were made by the IMF and the EBRD. These were essentially balance models whose main aim was to see that there are no contradictions between basic premises as regards GDP structure, budget, the balance of payments and the balance of savings. A group of Russian experts is already developing a medium-range econometric model. The U.S. Treasury is expected to help in the implementation of that task. It would be useful to combine all efforts under the Economic Analysis Office considering the broad possibilities of that organization in terms of enlisting the services of qualified consultants and the use of research results in the government's conduct of economic policy. Policv Note. Tactical Tasks of AIacroeconomic Policy and Structural Reform 2. Tax and Budget Policy. Regional Transfers. Social Sphere Financing The reduction of the state budget deficit and the rate of inflation has yet to bring about a cardinal improvement of Russia's financial position. The main cause is the contraction of budgetary expenditure because of the low tax collectability. Cuts in budget spending were not accompanied by adequate structural transformations. Budgetary spending is under heavy pressure to cover the losses of non-government enterprises. Another aspect of the current policy is substantial undercollection of taxes, largely due to indirect support of virtual bankrupts through non-payments or direct failure to pay taxes to the federal budget.
 3 The issue of surrogate money, which has assumed dangerous proportions, is a way of avoiding taxes for enterprises and imposing budgetary restrictions on local budgets. In developing a tax and budgetary policy in Russia one has to bear in mind that the contributions of enterprises to the pension and social funds, which are impossible to cancel, account for more than 11 percent of the GDP. Structural aspects of thle fiscal policy. A comprehensive analysis of the factors which cause low tax collectability stemming from a lack of coherent structural policy is of primary importance. The solution of that problem hinges on a consistent development of effective mechanisms to remove the structural barriers in the way of tax payments into the federal budget. The role of subsidies in fiscal policy. In the first place, the scale and sources of hidden and overt subventions of various economic agents should be analyzed. Specifically, it is necessary to assess to what extent this is subsidized by federal and local budgets, and what role the off-budget funds play. The aim of this research is to find ways to reduce or eliminate the channels for unwarranted subsidizing. Medium-range budget strategy. A separate study must be devoted to the level and economic structure of budgetary spending and the size of the budget deficit. Such a study may provide the basis for budgetary strategy in the coming years. There must be a broad discussion of possible changes in government policy to ensure for the budget the role of stimulant of economic activity and a stabilizing macroeconomic factor. It would also be useful to assess the concrete significance of budgetary means for the financing of the economy and the servicing of the state debt and reveal the actual share of the sources that support these functions of the federal budget. Pilot Project. Reform of the Tax System in Terms of Macroeconomic Effectiveness. 3. Support of Entrepreneurship. Anti-Monopoly Policy, Natural Monopolies The Russian economy is still highly monopolized. One of the main causes is continued significant government participation in the economy and poor development of small and medium enterprises capable of competing with the former 'monsters". It is no accident that while incomes are substantially lower than in Europe, the prices for a number of goods, including daily necessities, have exceeded the average European level. The quality of the goods and services provided domestically is fairly low. This is particularly true of the services market where there is virtually no foreign competition. In some sectors services of acceptable quality are unavailable. Large-scale production and anti-monopoly policy. The high level of monopolization in the planned economy was intimately connected with the activities of giant industrial enterprises. Eliminating the consequences of former monopolism is complicated by the possible appearance of new entities which behave in a monopolistic way. These include the financial-industrial groups (FIGs), and vertically integrated oil companies. The main aspects of anti-monopoly policy that call for broad discussion and mutually coordinated decisions involve the study of the following issues:
 4 * what is the relationship, in terms of macro-economic effectiveness, between such methods of combating monopolism as downsizing of giant enterprises and the creation. instead, of small and medium production entities; * what is the actual impact on the degree of monopolization exerted by the activities of the FIGs, especially those created 'from the top' by administrative decree. Regulation of natural monopolies. It is necessary, above all, to determine the reasons why the corresponding law and regulatory acts fail to ensure effective control of the activities of natural monopolies and their expenditures. As a result, there is considerable room for arbitrary price-fixing and cross-subsidizing of tariffs and for providing inferior quality services. A possible answer to the problem could be a statutory act that would allow the prices and tariffs of natural monopolies to be challenged, specifically, when services are substandard. The problem of the merger of natural monopolies with government agencies called upon to regulate them must be the subject of broad public discussion. The analysis must take into account that the government ministries and departments all too often act as lobbies for the interests of the monopolies before the budget and the public, rather than instruments of supervising them. Consumer goods market. The consumer market has become quite competitive, mainly due to large amounts of imported goods. This prompts the need to study the issue to what extent the increase of import duties contributes to the monopolization of the consumer market, an issue that is of direct relevance to decision-making in the anti-monopoly sphere and in foreign trade. A distinct problem that calls for a preliminary study is the market policy of retail networks. Their prices are not going down despite the prerequisites for competitive behavior, which would seem to suggest the presence of a conspiracy or the existence of a single monopoly boss. To make decisions in this area it is necessary to find out whether the behavior of the owners of retail networks reflects a growing monopoly trend or some other processes. 4. Industrial Policy, Accumulation and Investments. Economic Growth Russia has not yet overcome an investment crisis. The volume of investment continues to shrink. Centralized expenditure as opposed to the own assets of enterprises still accounts for a comparatively large share of the sources of financing. The amount of borrowed financial resources is insignificant. This is true of bank credits and foreign investments as well as the savings of households. Along with an obvious structural shift of investment toward the services sphere there remain sectors which have been virtually untouched by market transformations -- the Military-industrial Complex and agriculture. Main types and sources of accumulation. In view of the fact that less than half of the total volume of depreciation deductions goes into investments it is necessary to determine
 5 what the state can do to change the situation. One should draw attention to such possible measures as the development of more detailed standards of writing-off, account of the changes in the cost of certain types of assets and their regular re-evaluation, and strict control of the use of depreciation deductions. The profits of enterprises as a source of financing cannot be increased through direct government intervention. Even so, two specific questions require analysis: a) to what extent a cut of profit tax can enlarge the accumulation fund given poor tax collection and a lack of inclination to invest; b) what can be the impact, in terms of giving a greater role to profit in financing, of the creation of German-type long-term pension funds whose assets are used by companies as borrowed capital and are included in the liabilities of the balance sheet. Extending the range of financing channels. Analysis must focus, first, on finding out to what extent the removal from circulation of quasi-money and surrogate money used only for current transaction settlements (treasury bonds and tax exemptions, growing mass of bills of exchange issued against government guarantees) will increase real money supply; and second, how a reduction of the budget deficit will affect the growth of accumulations. Conditions for accumulation. It would be useful to conduct an empirical study to determine to what extent accumulation is stimulated by the desire to invest as a result of economic stability and by the development of the legal mechanisms of reform. The real condition for growing investments may be a cut of the real interest rate and reduction of the share of government borrowing which creates a 'displacement effect' in the credit market. The question of the impact of the state on resumption of economic growth through a full- scale industrial policy and revision of the basic approach to privatization calls for serious analysis. Possibilities of economic growth. The main factors of economic growth should be monitored. To assist the Bureau in achieving its impact objectives, the Bank would finance an independent evaluation of BEA outputs every two years as part of Bank supervision activities.

doc.repnme: Russian Federation - Bureau of Economic Analysis Project
doc.abstracts: The principal development objective of the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) Project is to build institutional capacity for sound economic analysis in support of market-oriented structural reforms. To meet this objective, the project has three sub-goals: (1) to increase the quantity and quality of cross-sectoral economic policy studies for government use; (2) to establish the BEA outside of but accountable to government, for an objective, economy-wide perspective in assessing economic policy options, and (3) to improve the reliability of the national accounts as a basis for sound economic analysis. The project will finance three components: (1) Policy studies- for local and international consultants, and to obtain data to use in medium-term policy studies focused on macroeconomic analysis and public finance, social policy, and enterprise economics and financial sector reform; for production of the annual report, quarterly indicators, and quick-response policy notes, and for databases to support these initiatives; (2) Bureau of Economic Analysis- for the technical and human resources needed to increase capacity for economic policy analysis both in the BEA and in the core economic ministries, including computer and information technology, a library, on-line databases, and training, study tours, and fellowships; and (3) Improvement of national accounts- for computer equipment, training, and technical assistance needed to improve the quality of economic statistics.
